name: Affenpinscher
temperament: Confident, alert, playful, loyal, courageous
description: Small, sturdy toy breed with a distinctive monkey-like expression and shaggy, wiry coat. Known for its confident, terrier-like personality despite its small size.
history: Originating in 17th-century Germany, bred down from larger terriers to be skilled ratters in homes, kitchens and stables. Refined in Munich and Berlin, recognized by AKC in 1936. Name translates to 'monkey-like terrier'.

name: Afghan Hound
temperament: Independent, dignified, aloof, loyal, confident
description: Ancient, elegant sighthound with dramatic, flowing silky coat and aristocratic bearing, bred for hunting large prey in mountainous terrain
history: Ancient sighthound originating in the mountainous regions of Afghanistan, where they were prized for hunting large prey like gazelles and leopards. Valued for their speed, stamina, and problem-solving intelligence over rugged terrain. Introduced to the Western world by British officers in the early 20th century.

name: Airedale Terrier
temperament: Confident, intelligent, courageous, alert, energetic, outgoing
description: The largest of all terrier breeds, the Airedale is a large, athletic dog with a distinctive wiry black and tan coat and confident, alert demeanor. Known as the 'King of Terriers', this highly intelligent and versatile breed combines courage with an outgoing temperament.
history: Developed in the Aire Valley of Yorkshire, England, by crossing Otterhounds with various terrier breeds. Originally bred by working-class fanciers to hunt otters and rats, their intelligence and courage led to their use as police dogs, war dogs, and all-around companions.

name: Akbash
temperament: Independent, protective, calm, alert, loyal, intelligent
description: Large, powerful, all-white livestock guardian dog from Turkey with lean athletic build, known for its independent nature and strong protective instincts. The distinctive white coat helped shepherds distinguish it from predators at a distance.
history: Ancient breed developed over 3,000 years ago in western Turkey for guarding livestock, particularly in the Akbash region. The white coat helped shepherds distinguish the dogs from predators. Introduced to North America in the 1970s for predator control programs.

name: Akita
temperament: Courageous, loyal, dignified, independent, protective, alert
description: A large, powerful spitz-type dog of Japanese origin with a bear-like head, dense double coat, and full curled tail. Known for its dignified presence, imposing stature, and courageous, loyal temperament.
history: Ancient Japanese breed developed in the mountainous Akita prefecture for hunting large game including wild boar and bear. Revered in Japanese culture as a symbol of health, happiness, and good fortune. The breed was nearly lost after World War II but was preserved by dedicated breeders and designated as a national treasure in Japan.

name: Alapaha Blue Blood Bulldog
temperament: Loyal, protective, intelligent, confident, alert
origin: Alapaha River region of southern Georgia, United States
description: A powerful, athletic bulldog breed with distinctive blue merle or patched coat patterns and muscular build. Originally developed as a 'catch dog' for farm work, livestock protection, and family guardian with strong protective instincts.
history: Developed in the Alapaha River region of southern Georgia as a multi-purpose catch dog for working cattle and hogs, and as a family guardian. Descended from Old English Bulldogs and recreated the original plantation bulldogs of the 1800s, maintained by the Lane family.

name: Alaskan Husky
temperament: Energetic, intelligent, work-focused, athletic, friendly, independent
description: Medium-sized athletic sled dog bred for performance rather than appearance, with variable coat colors and exceptional endurance. Built for speed and arctic conditions, this working dog represents a blend of various Northern breeds and pointers optimized for sled racing.
history: Developed in Alaska as a purpose-bred sled dog through selective breeding of various northern breeds (Siberian Husky, Alaskan Malamute, Inuit dogs) with European breeds like Pointers, Greyhounds, and Salukis to create the ideal combination of speed, endurance, and work ethic for sled racing

name: Alaskan Malamute
temperament: Affectionate, friendly, loyal, playful, intelligent, energetic, outgoing
description: An immensely strong, heavy-duty freighting dog of spitz type, the Alaskan Malamute is a large, powerful Arctic sled dog with a thick double coat, deep chest, well-muscled body, wolf-like appearance, and characteristically plumed tail carried over the back
history: One of the oldest Arctic sled dogs, developed by the native Mahlemut Inuit tribe of northwestern Alaska. Essential for survival, used for hauling heavy freight across Arctic terrain, hunting large predators like seals and polar bears

name: American Bulldog
temperament: Confident, loyal, protective, energetic, affectionate, courageous
description: A powerful, athletic, short-coated dog of the molosser type with a broad head and muscular build, known for its confidence, strength, and loyalty as a family companion and guardian. Originally bred for farm work and protection.
history: Descended from Old English Bulldogs brought by working-class immigrants to the American South. Developed as versatile all-around farm utility dogs for guarding property, catching livestock, and protection. The breed was preserved from near extinction after WWII by breeders John D. Johnson and Alan Scott.

name: American Bully
temperament: Confident, gentle, loyal, affectionate, outgoing, eager to please
description: A compact, muscular companion breed with a powerfully built body, broad head, and confident demeanor. Known for its gentle, affectionate nature and loyalty to family, the American Bully was developed from American Pit Bull Terriers and other bully breeds to create an excellent companion dog with a stable temperament.
history: Developed in the United States between the 1980s and 1990s as a companion breed through selective breeding of American Pit Bull Terriers, American Staffordshire Terriers, and other bulldog-type breeds to produce a dog with a gentler temperament and more muscular, 'bullier' physique. Recognized by the United Kennel Club in 2013.

name: American Cocker Spaniel
temperament: Gentle, smart, happy, outgoing, affectionate
description: The smallest member of the Sporting Group, the American Cocker Spaniel is a medium-sized sporting dog with a beautifully chiseled head, long flowing silky coat, long ears, and gentle expression
history: Developed in the United States from English Cocker Spaniels brought over in the late 1800s. American breeders selected for smaller size, more refined head, and heavier coat for woodcock hunting, leading to recognition as a separate breed by the AKC in 1946

name: American Eskimo Dog
temperament: Intelligent, alert, friendly, playful, energetic, eager to please
description: Compact spitz-type companion dog with distinctive dense white double coat, black points on lips, nose, and eye rims, wedge-shaped head, and plumed tail carried over the back. Available in three sizes (toy, miniature, standard) with an alert expression and striking appearance.
history: Descended from white German Spitz dogs brought to America by German immigrants. Name changed from German Spitz to American Eskimo Dog during World War I due to anti-German sentiment. Became popular circus performers in the 19th and early 20th centuries, recognized by AKC in 1994

name: American Foxhound
temperament: Independent, friendly, gentle, energetic, intelligent
description: A sleek, powerful scenthound with a long, fine-boned body and athletic build, known for incredible stamina, speed, and melodious baying voice. One of the oldest American-bred dogs, developed for endurance and pack hunting.
history: Developed from English Foxhounds imported to Colonial America in the 1650s, refined for American terrain and fox hunting. George Washington was a key figure in the breed's development, breeding them to be lighter, taller, and faster for hunting American red fox over varied terrain.

name: American Pit Bull Terrier
temperament: Confident, intelligent, loyal, affectionate, eager to please, energetic
description: Medium-sized, muscular terrier with athletic build and short coat, known for its strength, confidence, intelligence, and affectionate nature towards people. Possesses great strength for its size and is both athletic and agile.
history: Developed in the late 19th century from English bull-and-terrier breeds brought to America. Originally bred for bull-baiting and later refined as all-around farm dogs and loyal family companions. First recognized by the United Kennel Club in 1898.

name: American Staffordshire Terrier
temperament: Confident, courageous, loyal, intelligent, smart
description: A muscular, stocky, but agile medium-sized terrier of remarkable strength with a broad head, strong build, smooth coat and confident, good-natured personality
history: Developed in the 19th century from crosses of bulldogs and terriers brought to America in the 1800s. Originally bred for bull-baiting and pit fighting, later refined to be larger than English Staffordshire Bull Terriers and developed into all-purpose farm dogs and family companions. Recognized by the AKC in 1936.

name: American Water Spaniel
temperament: Eager to please, intelligent, energetic, alert, happy
description: Medium-sized versatile sporting dog with distinctive curly or wavy chocolate or liver coat, bred for hunting waterfowl in the icy waters and marshy banks of the Great Lakes region
history: Developed in the 19th century in the Fox and Wolf River valleys of Wisconsin as a compact, versatile hunter that could work from a skiff or boat. Ancestry likely includes Irish Water Spaniel and Curly-Coated Retriever. Named the state dog of Wisconsin in 1985 and foundation breed for the Boykin Spaniel, recognized by AKC in 1940.

name: Appenzeller Sennenhund
temperament: Energetic, intelligent, confident, loyal, alert, work-focused
description: Medium-sized, muscular and agile Swiss mountain dog with distinctive tricolor coat and tightly curled tail carried over the back. Known for their lively, self-assured expression and work-focused temperament, this ancient breed combines herding instincts with guarding abilities.
history: One of the four Swiss Sennenhund breeds, this ancient breed from the Appenzell region was used for centuries as an all-purpose farm dog for herding cattle, guarding property, and pulling carts. Formally established in the late 19th century through the efforts of forester Max Siber and Professor Albert Heim.

name: Australian Cattle Dog
temperament: Intelligent, alert, loyal, energetic, courageous
description: Compact, muscular working dog with distinctive coat markings and exceptional endurance for cattle herding; known as the Heeler
history: Developed in 19th century Australia by crossing British herding dogs including blue merle Collies with native Dingo, with later infusions of Dalmatian and Black and Tan Kelpie to create a hardy cattle herding dog for harsh Australian conditions

name: Australian Kelpie
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, loyal, work-focused, alert
description: Medium-sized athletic herding dog with exceptional energy and intelligence, developed for working sheep over vast distances in harsh Australian conditions. Known for their lithe, agile build and inexhaustible work ethic.
history: Developed in Australia during the late 19th century from crosses of imported Scottish Collies with Dingoes and other working dogs to create the ultimate sheep herding dog capable of working independently over vast distances in harsh climates

name: Australian Shepherd
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, work-focused, loyal, devoted, athletic
description: Medium-sized, agile herding dog with striking multicolored coat, expressive eyes, and keen herding instincts. Known for their intense work drive and weather-resistant double coat.
history: Despite its name, the Australian Shepherd was developed in the American West in the 19th century from Basque shepherd dogs brought by immigrants from the Pyrenees region. The breed's intelligence and versatility made it popular on the rodeo circuit and for ranching work.

name: Australian Silky Terrier
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, alert, energetic, confident
description: A small, spirited toy terrier with a refined but substantial build, characterized by its long, straight, glossy blue-and-tan silky coat that is parted down the middle and lively, alert demeanor
history: Developed in Australia in the late 19th century by crossing Yorkshire Terriers with Australian Terriers to create a small companion dog with a long, silky coat, combining hardiness with refined features and vermin hunting ability

name: Australian Terrier
temperament: Courageous, alert, friendly, loyal, intelligent
description: Small, sturdy terrier with harsh double coat and distinctive topknot, known for its spirited, alert expression and courageous personality
history: Developed in Australia during the 19th century from British terrier breeds including Cairn, Skye, and Yorkshire Terriers. Bred as all-purpose exterminators of rodents and snakes, as well as loyal watchdogs and companions. Recognized by AKC in 1960.

name: Azawakh
temperament: Independent, loyal, alert, protective, affectionate, aloof
origin: West Africa (Sahel region: Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso)
description: Elegant, tall sighthound from West Africa with a lean, muscular build, fine coat, and long legs built for speed and endurance in desert conditions of the Sahel region
history: Ancient sighthound breed developed by nomadic Tuareg peoples of the Sahel region for hunting gazelle and other game, protecting livestock, and serving as companions. Bred for speed and stamina in Saharan and Sahelian conditions

name: Barbet
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, loyal, playful, athletic, devoted
description: Medium-sized French water dog with distinctive long, dense, curly coat and webbed feet, bred for waterfowl retrieval. Known for its rustic, athletic build and joyful, intelligent disposition.
history: Ancient French water dog dating to 16th century, used for centuries to locate, flush and retrieve waterfowl in marshes and rivers. The breed's name derives from 'barbe' meaning beard. Nearly extinct after WWI but revived through dedicated breeding programs. Considered ancestor to several modern breeds including the Poodle and Briard. Officially recognized by the AKC in 2020.

name: Basenji
temperament: Independent, intelligent, alert, energetic, curious, affectionate
description: Small, elegant sighthound from Central Africa with a tightly curled tail, wrinkled forehead, and smooth coat. Known as the 'barkless dog' for its unique yodel-like vocalizations instead of traditional barking.
history: Ancient breed originating in Central Africa, depicted in Egyptian and Babylonian art. Prized by Pygmy tribes and Congo region tribes as versatile hunters for their speed and silence. Brought to England in the 1930s and established in the West.

name: Basset Bleu de Gascogne
temperament: Gentle, friendly, alert, loyal, independent
description: Medium-sized, low-slung French scent hound with distinctive blue-mottled coat, long drooping ears, and exceptional tracking abilities. Known for its noble expression and remarkable sense of smell.
history: Descended from the larger Grand Bleu de Gascogne developed in medieval Gascony region for hunting small game. Nearly extinct but revived in early 20th century by breeder Alain Bourbon

name: Basset Hound
temperament: Friendly, calm, gentle, loyal, independent, devoted
description: Low-slung, heavy-boned scent hound with distinctive long, velvety ears, mournful expression, and loose skin. Known for powerful tracking ability and calm demeanor.
history: Developed by French aristocrats from hounds bred at the Abbey of St. Hubert for hunting small game in dense cover. Low-slung body perfected for trailing rabbits and hare, later refined in England for pack hunting.

name: Beagle
temperament: Friendly, gentle, alert, outgoing, curious, energetic
description: Compact, merry scent hound with sturdy build, distinctive tri-color or bi-color coat pattern, and cheerful disposition. Originally bred for hunting hare in packs with a distinctive baying voice.
history: The modern Beagle was developed in Great Britain around the 1830s from various English hounds. Bred as 'foot hounds' for hare hunting, with hunters following on foot rather than horseback.

name: Bearded Collie
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, playful, affectionate, alert, confident, outgoing
description: Medium-sized herding dog with long, shaggy double coat and animated expression, known for its boisterous, charismatic personality and distinctive bouncing gait
history: Ancient Scottish herding breed developed to drive sheep and cattle in harsh Highland conditions, bred for hardiness, intelligence, and ability to work independently. Nearly extinct after World War II but revived through careful breeding programs. Recognized by Kennel Club in 1959 and AKC in 1977.

name: Beauceron
temperament: Intelligent, loyal, protective, courageous, confident
description: Large, powerful French herding dog with distinctive double dewclaws, short double coat, and black and tan markings. Known for its self-assured demeanor and versatility as both guardian and companion.
history: Ancient French herding breed also known as Berger de Beauce, developed in plains surrounding Paris for herding and protecting sheep and cattle. Shares ancestry with the Briard, nearly extinct after World War II but saved by dedicated breeders. Also used for military and police work.

name: Bedlington Terrier
temperament: Intelligent, affectionate, energetic, playful, courageous, alert
description: Distinctive lamb-like terrier with graceful, lithe build, arched back, pear-shaped head, and crisp curly coat that gives it a unique appearance among terrier breeds
history: Developed in Bedlington, Northumberland in the early 19th century for hunting vermin in mines and farms. Known as the 'Gypsy Dog' due to use by poachers. Lineage includes Dandie Dinmont Terrier, Whippet, and Otterhound crosses. Recognized by The Kennel Club in 1877 and AKC in 1886.

name: Belgian Malinois
temperament: Intelligent, confident, energetic, loyal, alert, work-focused, protective
description: Medium-sized, athletic herding dog that is squarely built with a proud carriage. Known for its intense intelligence and strong work ethic, particularly suited for police and military roles. Features a short fawn-to-mahogany coat with distinctive black mask and ears.
history: Developed in the area around Malines, Belgium, in the late 19th century as one of four varieties of Belgian Shepherd dogs. Originally bred for herding ability and strong work ethic, quickly adopted by police forces and militaries worldwide. AKC recognized as distinct breed in 1959.

name: Belgian Tervuren
temperament: Intelligent, courageous, alert, loyal, energetic
description: Elegant, athletic medium-sized herding dog with a long double coat ranging from rich fawn to mahogany with black overlay, known for intelligence, versatility and strong work drive
history: One of four distinct Belgian sheepdog varieties developed in the late 1800s, named after the village of Tervuren. Originally used as a versatile herding and guard dog for flocks, prized for intelligence, trainability and work ethic

name: Bernese Mountain Dog
temperament: Calm, gentle, loyal, intelligent, affectionate, good-natured
description: Large, strong, and sturdy working dog with a distinctive long tricolored coat and calm, gentle temperament. One of four types of Swiss Mountain Dogs, known for being good-natured, loyal, and an excellent family companion.
history: One of four types of Swiss Mountain Dogs originating in the canton of Bern. Served as all-purpose farm dogs for droving cattle, pulling carts to market, and watchdogs. Nearly extinct by early 1900s but revived through careful breeding programs

name: Bichon Frisé
temperament: Happy, playful, affectionate, intelligent, gentle, energetic
description: A small, sturdy, and cheerful companion dog with a soft, curly white double coat, black eyes, and a lively, playful disposition
history: Descended from the Barbet, a Mediterranean water spaniel. The breed was developed in France and became a popular companion dog for European nobility. The modern breed standard was established in France after World War I.

name: Black and Tan Coonhound
temperament: Friendly, outgoing, intelligent, alert, adaptable, easygoing
description: Large, powerful American-bred scent hound with distinctive black and tan coat pattern and long ears, known for its cold nose, loud bawling bark, and determined trailing ability
history: Developed in the American South by frontiersmen in the 18th century, descending from English Foxhound, Bloodhound, and Talbot Hound crosses for raccoon hunting and tracking over rugged Appalachian terrain

name: Bloodhound
temperament: Gentle, friendly, independent, alert, devoted, affectionate
description: Large, substantial scent hound with a noble, dignified expression, characterized by exceptional tracking ability, distinctive wrinkled face, long drooping ears, loose skin, and pendulous jowls. Renowned for its extraordinary sense of smell and unparalleled tracking abilities.
history: Ancient breed developed by monks at the Abbey of Saint-Hubert in Belgium and France during medieval times. Later refined in England and valued for centuries for tracking game and people, eventually imported to the US for search and rescue work.

name: Bluetick Coonhound
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, loyal, devoted, work-focused
description: Large, athletic, and muscular scenthound with distinctive blue-ticked coat pattern and renowned 'cold nose' trailing ability, bred specifically for tracking and treeing raccoons
history: Developed in Louisiana from French Grand Bleu de Gascogne hounds crossed with English Foxhounds, American Foxhounds, and other local coonhound breeds, perfected for raccoon hunting in American terrain

name: Boerboel
temperament: Confident, intelligent, loyal, protective, calm
description: Large, powerful mastiff-type guardian breed from South Africa with a muscular build, short dense coat, and confident temperament. Known as a family guardian, the name 'Boerboel' translates to 'farmer's dog' in Afrikaans.
history: Developed by Dutch and other European settlers in South Africa starting in the 1600s from European mastiff breeds and native dogs. Bred as all-purpose farm dogs for protecting homesteads from predators.

name: Border Collie
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, alert, work-focused, loyal, eager to please
description: Medium-sized, highly intelligent, and athletic herding dog with keen expression and intense work drive, renowned for its instinctual ability to control livestock with its signature stare
history: Developed by shepherds on the border of England and Scotland for herding sheep in hilly terrain, refined through selective breeding for working ability. The breed's lineage can be traced back to a single dog named Old Hemp, born in 1893.

name: Border Terrier
temperament: Affectionate, intelligent, alert, energetic, courageous, adaptable
origin: Border regions between England and Scotland
description: Small, sturdy working terrier with weather-resistant wiry coat and distinctive otter-like head, bred for fox hunting with a plucky and affectionate nature
history: Developed in the 18th century in the Cheviot Hills along the English-Scottish border by farmers and shepherds to hunt fox alongside foxhounds. Needed to be small enough to follow quarry into dens and burrows but tough enough to keep up with horses and work independently.

name: Boston Terrier
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, outgoing, playful
description: Compact, short-tailed dog with distinctive flat face, erect ears, and smooth 'tuxedo' coat markings. Known as 'The American Gentleman' for its friendly and intelligent demeanor.
history: Developed in Boston in the 1870s from crossing English Bulldog with the now-extinct White English Terrier. Refined in the late 19th century and became one of the first American-developed breeds recognized by the AKC.

name: Bouvier des Flandres
temperament: Loyal, intelligent, protective, courageous, calm, gentle
description: Large, powerfully built herding dog with a rugged appearance and rough, tousled double coat. This compact breed gives the impression of great strength without heaviness and has a dense weather-resistant coat suited for farm work.
history: Developed by monks in the Flanders region of medieval Europe as cattle herding and all-purpose farm dog. Used to drive cattle, pull carts, and serve as a watchdog. Nearly extinct after World War I but revived by dedicated breeders.

name: Boxer
temperament: Playful, energetic, loyal, intelligent, friendly, alert
description: Medium to large, powerful and athletic working dog with a distinctive short-muzzled, flat face and short coat. Known for their fun-loving, bright temperament and expressive face, combining energy with loyalty.
history: Developed in late 19th century Germany from the now-extinct German Bullenbeisser (used for hunting large game like boar and bear) and English Bulldog, originally for bull-baiting and hunting, later refined for working and companion roles

name: Boykin Spaniel
temperament: Friendly, energetic, eager to please, intelligent, adaptable
description: Medium-sized, energetic, and versatile flushing and retrieving spaniel with rich liver or chocolate brown coat and enthusiastic work ethic, especially in water. Known for their amiable disposition and compact build ideal for hunting from small boats.
history: Developed in early 1900s in South Carolina by L. Whitaker Boykin. Foundation sire was a small stray spaniel-type dog named 'Dumpy' who showed great hunting aptitude. Bred by crossing Chesapeake Bay Retrievers, Springer Spaniels, Cocker Spaniels, and American Water Spaniels for hunting in South Carolina swamps, particularly the Wateree River Swamp. Recognized as the state dog of South Carolina.

name: Bracco Italiano
temperament: Gentle, intelligent, affectionate, loyal, calm, docile, adaptable
description: Large, noble Italian pointing breed with sculpted head, distinctive orange and white or chestnut and white coat, and pendulous ears. A powerful and athletic dog of ancient Italian lineage, known for its endurance and gentle, intelligent nature.
history: One of the oldest pointing breeds in Europe with ancient origins dating back to the 4th-5th century BC. Developed as a versatile hunting dog for bird hunting in Italian terrain, adept at pointing and retrieving. The modern breed is thought to be a cross of the Piedmontese Pointer and the Lombard Pointer.

name: Briard
temperament: Loyal, intelligent, protective, confident, courageous, devoted
description: Large, powerful French herding dog with a luxurious long wavy double coat, distinctive beard and eyebrows creating a peek-a-boo hairdo, and a loyal, intelligent disposition
history: Ancient French herding breed developed for centuries to herd and guard flocks. Served as sentries, messengers, and pack animals for the French army during World War I. Nearly extinct after World War II but successfully revived. Recognized by the AKC in 1928.

name: Brittany
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, eager to please, friendly, athletic, happy
description: Medium-sized, compact and leggy sporting dog with an athletic build and distinctive orange and white feathered coat. Known for its versatility in pointing and retrieving, this agile gundog combines high energy for hunting and field work with an intelligent and happy-go-lucky disposition.
history: Developed in the 17th-18th century in the Brittany province of France as a versatile hunting dog capable of pointing and retrieving on various terrain. Refined through crosses with English Setters and recognized by AKC in 1934.

name: Bullmastiff
temperament: Loyal, protective, calm, courageous, affectionate, confident
description: Large, powerful guardian breed with short coat and calm, confident demeanor, originally bred to guard estates and known as 'The Gamekeeper's Night-Dog'
history: Developed in mid-19th century England by gamekeepers crossing English Mastiff with Old English Bulldog to create an effective estate guard dog for tracking poachers

name: Bull Terrier
temperament: Playful, courageous, energetic, loyal, mischievous
description: A muscular, well-built terrier best known for its distinctive long, egg-shaped head that slopes down to the nose. This confident breed combines a playful, mischievous personality with a courageous temperament.
history: Developed in 19th-century England by crossing old English Bulldogs with various terriers, originally for bull-baiting and dog fighting. James Hinks is credited with standardizing the breed and creating the distinctive egg-shaped head, earning them the nickname 'The White Cavalier'.

name: Bull Terrier (Miniature)
temperament: Playful, energetic, courageous, confident, affectionate, outgoing
description: Small, upstanding, and muscular terrier with a distinctive egg-shaped head and triangular eyes. This compact version of the Bull Terrier is known for being comical, mischievous, and lively with a squarely built frame.
history: Developed in 19th-century England as a scaled-down version of the standard Bull Terrier, which was standardized by James Hinks. Created for fanciers who wanted a smaller companion version while maintaining the same characteristics and recognized as a separate breed by the AKC in 1991.

name: Cairn Terrier
temperament: Alert, confident, friendly, intelligent, courageous, energetic
description: A small, sturdy working terrier with weather-resistant shaggy coat and alert expression, originating from the Scottish Highlands and known for its plucky, cheerful nature
history: Developed on the Isle of Skye in Scotland, one of the oldest terrier breeds. Originally used by farmers in the Scottish Highlands to hunt and flush out foxes and vermin from rock piles (cairns), which gave the breed its name. Recognized by the AKC in 1913.

name: Cane Corso
temperament: Confident, protective, intelligent, loyal, affectionate
description: Large, powerful Italian mastiff-type dog with muscular, athletic build and confident demeanor. This intelligent and majestic breed was historically used as a guardian and hunter, known for its loyalty to family.
history: Ancient Italian breed descended from Roman Molossian war dogs, developed as a versatile farmhand, guardian, and hunter of large game. The breed nearly faced extinction but was revived by enthusiasts in the 1970s.

name: Cardigan Welsh Corgi
temperament: Affectionate, loyal, intelligent, alert, adaptable
description: Low-set, sturdily built herding dog with a long body, fox-like brushy tail, and rounded ears, known for intelligence and versatility
history: One of the oldest herding breeds, believed brought to Wales by Celtic tribes around 1200 BC, developed as versatile farm dogs for cattle herding and property guarding

name: Catahoula Leopard Dog
temperament: Independent, intelligent, loyal, protective, energetic, work-focused
description: Medium to large, athletic herding and hunting breed known for its distinctive spotted or merle coat patterns, striking heterochromatic (glass) eyes, and strong work ethic. This versatile working dog combines intelligence with independence.
history: Developed in Northern Louisiana from Native American dogs crossed with Spanish and French settlers' dogs for hunting feral hogs and herding cattle. Named after Catahoula Parish and designated as the official state dog of Louisiana.

name: Caucasian Shepherd Dog
temperament: Protective, independent, confident, courageous, alert
description: Massive, powerful livestock guardian breed with thick, weather-resistant double coat, originally bred to protect flocks from large predators like wolves and bears in the Caucasus Mountains. This formidable guardian combines strong protective instincts with courageous temperament.
history: Ancient breed developed in the Caucasus Mountain region to protect flocks from large predators like wolves and bears, as well as human thieves. Selectively bred by shepherds for protection ability, later utilized by the Soviet Union as military and prison guard dogs

name: Cavalier King Charles Spaniel
temperament: Affectionate, gentle, friendly, playful, eager to please, adaptable
description: Small, elegant toy spaniel with silky coat, large expressive eyes, and noble appearance, known for its gentle expression and affectionate temperament, equally at home as a lap dog or active companion
history: Named after King Charles II who favored the breed, descended from toy spaniels depicted in 16th-18th century British court paintings. The modern breed was revived in the 1920s by enthusiasts seeking to restore the longer-nosed type seen in old portraits

name: Chesapeake Bay Retriever
temperament: Intelligent, courageous, loyal, protective, confident
description: A powerful, muscular gundog with distinctive wavy, waterproof double coat and amber eyes, bred for retrieving waterfowl in the harsh conditions of the Chesapeake Bay
history: Developed in the 19th century along the Chesapeake Bay from two shipwrecked Newfoundland-type puppies (Sailor and Canton) bred with local retrievers to create a water gundog capable of withstanding icy conditions and retrieving waterfowl in harsh environments

name: Chinese Crested
temperament: Affectionate, alert, playful, lively, intelligent, gentle
description: Small, elegant toy dog with fine-boned build that comes in two distinctive varieties: the Hairless with soft skin and tufts of hair, and the Powderpuff with a soft, straight double coat
history: Ancient breed believed to have descended from African or Mexican hairless dogs and refined in China. Chinese mariners kept them on ships to hunt vermin and traded them among port cities worldwide. Served as companions to Chinese nobility and were believed to possess magical healing powers

name: Chinese Shar-Pei
temperament: Loyal, independent, calm, alert, protective, intelligent
description: An ancient Chinese breed known for its distinctive deep wrinkles, hippopotamus-like muzzle, blue-black tongue, and compact, medium-sized build with a calm, independent temperament
history: Ancient Chinese breed from southern provinces dating back to the Han Dynasty, originally used as all-purpose farm dog for hunting, herding, guarding, and farm work. Nearly extinct in mid-20th century but revived from very small population by dedicated breeders in 1970s

name: Chinook
temperament: Intelligent, calm, devoted, friendly, eager to please
description: Large, athletic American sled dog with distinctive tawny double coat, known for combining strength, endurance, and a calm, gentle temperament. This versatile working breed was developed for drafting and sled-dog racing in New England conditions.
history: Developed in the early 20th century by polar explorer Arthur Treadwell Walden by crossing Mastiff-type dogs with Huskies and Belgian Shepherds. Named after the foundation male 'Chinook', bred to be an ideal sled dog for New England conditions. Recognized by the AKC in 2013.

name: Chow Chow
temperament: Loyal, independent, aloof, alert, calm, protective
description: An ancient, powerful, and sturdily built dog of Arctic spitz-type, known for its distinctive lion-like mane, unique blue-black tongue, stilted gait, and dense double coat
history: One of the oldest recognizable breeds with origins dating back over 2,000 years in northern China, where it served as hunting, herding, guarding, and companion dog. Refined during Tang Dynasty and recognized by AKC in 1903.

name: Clumber Spaniel
temperament: Gentle, loyal, calm, intelligent, playful
description: A long, low, and substantial flushing spaniel with a massive head, heavy bone structure, pensive expression, and predominantly white coat with lemon or orange markings
history: Developed in the 18th century, associated with the French Duc de Noailles and Duke of Newcastle's Clumber Park estate in Nottinghamshire. Likely developed from Alpine Spaniel, Basset Hound crosses. Prized by British royalty and nobility as gentleman's hunting spaniels for game flushing

name: Cocker Spaniel
temperament: Friendly, affectionate, playful, intelligent, outgoing
description: Compact sporting breed with silky coat, merry expression, and affectionate nature
history: Descended from English Cocker Spaniels, developed in the US for smaller size and specialized for woodcock hunting; officially recognized as a distinct breed by the AKC in 1946

name: Coton de Tulear
temperament: Happy, playful, affectionate, alert, friendly, intelligent, adaptable
description: Small companion dog with soft cotton-like white coat, charming personality and cheerful temperament
history: Originated as royal dog and companion to nobles in Madagascar, developed from small white dogs brought by traders. Named for city of Tuléar and recognized by FCI and AKC as beloved adaptable companion breed

name: Dalmatian
temperament: Energetic, outgoing, intelligent, alert, athletic
description: Medium-sized, athletic dog with distinctive black or liver spotted white coat and elegant build, originally bred as a carriage dog with exceptional endurance
history: Ancient breed with roots in Dalmatia, Croatia, originally bred as carriage dogs to run for miles alongside horse-drawn coaches, guarding horses and coaches. Also served as circus performers and iconic firehouse mascots, particularly associated with American fire departments. Recognized by AKC in 1888.

name: Doberman Pinscher
temperament: Intelligent, alert, loyal, energetic, confident
description: Medium-large, sleek, athletic and powerful dog known for exceptional loyalty and intelligence. This elegant working breed combines strength with agility and has a confident, alert demeanor.
history: Created in late 19th century by Karl Friedrich Louis Dobermann using breeds such as the Rottweiler, German Pinscher, and others for protection and companionship

name: Dogo Argentino
temperament: Courageous, loyal, protective, confident, intelligent, energetic
description: Large, powerful, all-white mastiff-type dog with massive head and athletic build, originally developed for big-game hunting with exceptional courage and strength
history: Developed in Argentina in the 1920s by Dr. Antonio Nores Martinez who systematically crossed the now-extinct Cordoba Fighting Dog with Great Dane, Boxer, Bull Terrier, and Pointer to create a versatile big-game hunter for wild boar and puma

name: Dutch Shepherd
temperament: Intelligent, loyal, alert, energetic, athletic, work-focused, independent
description: Medium-sized herding dog with athletic, muscular build and distinctive brindle coat pattern. An intelligent, versatile, and work-focused breed of Dutch origin that served as an all-purpose farm dog.
history: Developed in the Netherlands as an all-purpose farm dog for herding sheep and cattle, cart-pulling, and guarding. Nearly extinct after WWII but preserved through dedicated breeding efforts. Known for its brindle coat in three varieties: short, long, and wire-haired.

name: English Setter
temperament: Friendly, gentle, affectionate, intelligent, energetic
description: Elegant and athletic gundog distinguished by its unique speckled (belton) coat, feathered markings, and graceful movement, known for gentle hunting instincts and friendly disposition
history: Developed in England over 400 years ago from spaniel stock, refined in the 19th century by Edward Laverack and R. Purcell Llewellin to create a specialized bird dog for locating and setting game birds

name: English Shepherd
temperament: Intelligent, loyal, energetic, alert, devoted, adaptable
description: Exceptionally intelligent and versatile medium-sized herding dog with a dense double coat and strong work ethic, developed as an all-purpose farm dog with devotion to family and adaptable temperament
history: Developed in the United States from British and Scottish collie-type farm dogs brought by early settlers, bred as versatile all-purpose farm dogs for herding livestock, guarding property, and hunting vermin

name: English Springer Spaniel
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, energetic, eager to please, playful
description: Medium-sized athletic sporting dog with long ears, feathered silky coat, and enthusiastic, eager-to-please personality. Known for their compact body, gentle intelligent expression, and versatile gundog abilities.
history: Developed in 19th century England as a versatile gundog to find and 'spring' game for the net, falcon, or gun. Originally separated from smaller 'cocker' spaniels by size and hunting use. Officially recognized by The Kennel Club in 1902 and AKC in 1910.

name: English Toy Terrier (Black & Tan)
temperament: Alert, intelligent, loyal, playful
description: Small, elegant black and tan terrier with fine-boned build and distinctive pointed, candle-flame ears
history: Descended from the Old English Black and Tan Terrier, bred as a ratter in Victorian England and now a rare companion breed. Recognized by The Kennel Club (UK).

name: Eurasier
temperament: Calm, confident, loyal, intelligent, gentle, reserved
description: Medium-sized Spitz-type dog with balanced proportions and thick, plush double coat that comes in a variety of colors. Known for its calm, devoted nature and confident temperament.
history: Developed in Germany in the 1960s by Julius Wipfel by crossing Chow Chow, Wolfspitz (Keeshond), and Samoyed to create an ideal Spitz-type family companion dog. Recognized by the FCI.

name: Field Spaniel
temperament: Docile, intelligent, affectionate, gentle, sensitive
description: Medium-sized sporting dog with silky, glossy coat in black, liver, or roan colors, built for endurance and agility in the field with an adaptable, noble temperament
history: Developed in England during the late 19th century from Cocker Spaniels and other spaniel varieties, initially for show but later redeveloped for field work. The breed faced near extinction after World War II but was revived by dedicated breeders.

name: Finnish Lapphund
temperament: Friendly, alert, intelligent, calm, courageous, loyal, adaptable
description: Medium-sized, sturdy spitz-type dog with a thick profuse double coat and fox-like features, originally bred for herding reindeer in arctic conditions by the Sami people
history: Ancient spitz breed developed by the indigenous Sami people of Lapland to herd and guard reindeer in Arctic conditions. Nearly extinct after WWII but successfully restored by dedicated Finnish breeders, officially recognized by Finnish Kennel Club in 1945

name: Finnish Spitz
temperament: Friendly, alert, intelligent, independent, playful, courageous
description: Medium-sized fox-like spitz hunting dog with dense golden-red double coat, erect ears, curled plumed tail, and alert expression. Known as Finland's national dog and called the 'barking pointer' for their distinctive hunting style.
history: Ancient Finnish breed developed through centuries of selective breeding to hunt all types of game from squirrels to bears. Nearly extinct in late 1800s before restoration efforts. Became Finland's national dog in 1979, bred specifically for barking ability and stamina in harsh climates.

name: French Bulldog
temperament: Affectionate, playful, alert, adaptable, smart
description: Small, compact muscular companion dog known for its distinctive large bat-like ears, flat smooshed face, and short smooth coat. Originally developed as a beloved companion breed with a playful, alert disposition.
history: Developed in 19th century France when English lacemakers brought Toy Bulldogs to France and crossed them with local French ratters becoming highly fashionable in Parisian society

name: German Pinscher
temperament: Alert, courageous, intelligent, energetic, confident, loyal
description: Medium-sized, well-muscled working dog with elegant, athletic build and smooth coat. Known for its high-spirited, alert, and confident demeanor, this is one of Germany's oldest breeds.
history: Ancient German breed developed for vermin control, ratting, and farm work. Ancestor to the Doberman Pinscher and Miniature Pinscher. Nearly faced extinction after World War II but was revived by Werner Jung in West Germany in the late 1950s. Recognized by AKC in 2003.

name: German Shepherd
temperament: Confident, courageous, intelligent, loyal, protective
description: Large, athletic working dog with erect ears, noble expression, and confident bearing. Known for high intelligence, loyalty, courage, and versatility in herding and working roles.
history: Developed in 1899 by Captain Max von Stephanitz to create the ideal herding dog, standardized from local shepherd dogs. Intelligence and trainability led to worldwide use in police and military roles.

name: German Shorthaired Pointer
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, energetic, eager to please, athletic
description: A versatile, athletic, and noble all-purpose hunting dog with a distinctive short, dense liver and white coat, known for its intelligence, energy, and friendly disposition
history: Developed in 19th-century Germany by crossing Spanish Pointers, Bloodhound, and local German hunting dogs to create a versatile pointer-retriever capable of working on land and water. Recognized by AKC in 1930.

name: Giant Schnauzer
temperament: Loyal, intelligent, alert, energetic, courageous, confident
description: Large, powerful, and robust working dog with a dense wiry, weather-resistant coat, distinctive beard and eyebrows, and commanding, imposing presence. Originally bred for driving cattle and guarding in Germany.
history: Developed in Bavaria and Württemberg, Germany as a larger version of the Standard Schnauzer by crossing with larger breeds like the Great Dane. Originally used for driving cattle to market, guarding property, breweries and farms, and later as police and military working dogs.

name: Glen of Imaal Terrier
temperament: Courageous, gentle, loyal, intelligent, spirited
origin: Glen of Imaal, County Wicklow, Ireland
description: A strong, low-set working terrier of medium length with a sturdy, powerful build. Known for its harsh, weather-resistant double coat and courageous working temperament developed in the rugged Irish mountains.
history: Originated in the rugged Glen of Imaal valley as an all-around farm dog for hunting badgers and foxes, eradicating vermin, and historically used as turnspit dogs. Recognized by Irish Kennel Club in 1934 and AKC in 2004.

name: Golden Retriever
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, devoted, confident, loyal, eager to please
description: Large, athletic sporting dog with a dense, lustrous, flowing golden coat and friendly disposition, known for their versatility as family companions and working dogs
history: Developed in the Scottish Highlands during the mid-to-late 19th century by Dudley Marjoribanks (Lord Tweedmouth), who crossed a yellow retriever with the now-extinct Tweed Water Spaniel, with later additions of Irish Setter and Bloodhound for hunting and retrieving in rugged terrain and cold water

name: Gordon Setter
temperament: Confident, loyal, affectionate, intelligent, eager to please, alert
description: Large, athletic bird dog with distinctive glistening black-and-tan coat. Built sturdily for work in rugged terrain, it is the heaviest and most substantial of the setter breeds, known for endurance and loyalty with an alert expression.
history: Developed in Scotland by Alexander the fourth Duke of Gordon in the late 18th and early 19th centuries from black and tan setters. Established as a durable one-man bird dog capable of working long days in rugged Scottish Highland terrain.

name: Great Dane
temperament: Friendly, gentle, confident, loyal, affectionate
description: Giant, regal breed known as the 'Apollo of Dogs' with a powerful, well-muscled body, sleek coat, and dignified presence combined with noble bearing despite imposing size
history: Originally bred by German nobility from Mastiff-type dogs to hunt wild boar and deer, later refined as estate guardians and companions. Declared national dog of Germany in 1876 and standardized as 'Deutsche Dogge'

name: Greyhound
temperament: Gentle, calm, intelligent, affectionate, independent
description: An ancient sighthound with tall, lean, elegant build designed for exceptional speed. Known for their gentle temperament and often described as a '45-mph couch potato', combining incredible athleticism with calm, affectionate nature.
history: Ancient sighthound breed dating back thousands of years, depicted in Egyptian, Greek, and Roman art. The modern Greyhound was standardized in Great Britain for coursing game and later racing. Famed as the fastest dog breed.

name: Harrier
temperament: Friendly, outgoing, energetic, intelligent, gentle
description: Medium-sized athletic scent hound bred for pack hunting hare, resembling a smaller English Foxhound with sturdy build, short dense coat, and excellent stamina
history: Developed in medieval England for hare hunting in packs, documented since at least the 13th century. Likely descended from English Foxhound, Talbot Hounds, and other French hounds

name: Havanese
temperament: Outgoing, intelligent, friendly, playful, affectionate, adaptable
description: Small, sturdy companion dog with long, silky double coat and cheerful temperament. Cuba's national dog, known for its intelligent disposition and making an ideal city companion.
history: Developed from Bichon-type ancestors brought by Spanish settlers, became companions to Cuban aristocracy. Nearly extinct after Cuban Revolution but preserved by Cuban families who fled to the United States.

name: Irish Setter
temperament: Friendly, outgoing, energetic, intelligent, playful, affectionate
description: Elegant, athletic gundog known for its stunning mahogany or rich chestnut red flowing coat and high-energy, friendly temperament
history: Developed in 18th-century Ireland as a versatile gundog for setting and retrieving game birds by crossing Irish Water Spaniel, English Setter, and Pointer. The breed's striking mahogany color became a hallmark in the 19th century, distinguishing it from earlier red-and-white setters

name: Irish Terrier
temperament: Courageous, loyal, intelligent, energetic, spirited
description: Medium-sized terrier with a distinctive wiry, fiery red coat and bold, spirited temperament. Known for its courage and loyalty, it is one of the oldest terrier breeds.
history: One of the oldest terrier breeds, developed in County Cork, Ireland as all-purpose farm dogs for hunting vermin and guarding homes. Their courage was proven in World War I where they served as messenger dogs and sentinels.

name: Irish Wolfhound
temperament: Gentle, calm, dignified, courageous, loyal
description: A giant-sized sighthound of imposing appearance and dignified nature, the Irish Wolfhound is the tallest of all dog breeds. Known for its wiry, rough coat and gentle giant temperament, this ancient breed combines courage with a calm, dignified demeanor.
history: Ancient breed from Ireland originally used in war and for hunting wolves and Irish elk. Nearly extinct by the 1860s but revived by Captain George Augustus Graham who standardized the breed.

name: Italian Greyhound
temperament: Affectionate, gentle, playful, alert, intelligent
description: Elegant small sighthound with slender, delicate build and graceful movement, combining the look of a large hound with the size of a lap dog and fine, smooth coat
history: Ancient breed with origins tracing back over 2,000 years to the Mediterranean basin, favored by nobility in ancient Greece, Rome, and Italian Renaissance, AKC recognized since 1886

name: Japanese Chin
temperament: Alert, intelligent, affectionate, independent, playful, calm
description: Small, elegant toy breed with distinctive flat face, large wide-set eyes, and luxurious silky coat. Known for their aristocratic bearing and unique cat-like demeanor, often cleaning their faces and perching in high places.
history: Ancient breed believed to have originated in the Chinese imperial court, then refined in Japan by nobility as cherished lap dogs and companions. Often given as gifts to diplomats and royalty, including to Commodore Matthew Perry who brought them to the West in 1853.

name: Japanese Spitz
temperament: Intelligent, playful, alert, loyal, affectionate, friendly
description: Small to medium-sized spitz-type dog with profuse, pure-white double coat, fox-like face with pointed muzzle, and plumed tail carried over its back. This lively companion dog has an alert, friendly disposition.
history: Developed in Japan in the 1920s-1930s from various spitz breeds including large white German Spitz dogs brought to Japan around 1920. The breed was developed through selective breeding for friendly temperament and white coat, first exhibited in Tokyo in 1921. After World War II, the breed standard was unified by the Japan Kennel Club.

name: Kangal Shepherd Dog
temperament: Loyal, protective, independent, calm, intelligent, alert
description: Large, powerful, and heavy-boned livestock guardian dog with distinctive fawn coat, black mask and ears, and curled tail, bred for protecting flocks from predators
history: Ancient livestock guardian breed originating from the Kangal district in the Sivas province of Turkey. For centuries used by shepherds to protect flocks from wolves, bears, and jackals. Considered a national treasure in Turkey and valued for strength, loyalty, and independence.

name: Keeshond
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, outgoing, alert, eager to please
description: Medium-sized compact spitz with plush silver-gray double coat, fox-like face, distinctive spectacles markings around the eyes, and plumed tail curled over back
history: Ancient Dutch breed known as the Dutch Barge Dog, popular companion and watchdog on barges and riverboats along the Rhine River. Became symbol of Dutch Patriots Party in 18th century, nearly extinct after WWII but restored from dogs exported to England and America

name: King Charles Spaniel
temperament: Gentle, affectionate, intelligent, friendly, happy, playful
description: Small, compact toy spaniel with distinctive domed head, flat face, short nose, large dark eyes, long ears, and silky coat available in four color varieties (Blenheim, Tricolour, Ruby, and Black and Tan). Known as the English Toy Spaniel in the USA.
history: Descended from toy spaniels popular with European nobility since the 16th century, famously associated with King Charles II who favored companion spaniels. Modern flat-faced appearance developed through crossings with short-nosed Asian toy breeds in the 18th-19th centuries. The four color varieties were once considered separate breeds.

name: Komondor
temperament: Loyal, protective, independent, courageous, calm
description: Large, muscular Hungarian livestock guardian dog with distinctive heavy coat of white cords resembling a mop. Built for endurance and protection, this imposing breed possesses a dignified, courageous demeanor.
history: Ancient breed descended from Tibetan dogs brought to Hungary by nomadic Magyar tribes over a thousand years ago around 1000 AD. Developed to be formidable independent livestock guardian protecting sheep and cattle from wolves bears and harsh weather.

name: Kooikerhondje
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, alert, energetic, cheerful, adaptable
description: Small, agile spaniel-type dog of Dutch origin with a distinctive flowing orange-red and white particolored coat and feathered ears, originally bred for luring ducks into traps
history: Ancient Dutch breed developed as early as the 16th century to work as duck decoy dogs, luring ducks into traps called 'eendenkooien'. Nearly extinct after World War II but saved and re-established by Baroness van Hardenbroek van Ammerstol from remaining bloodlines. Recognized by AKC in 2018.

name: Kuvasz
temperament: Loyal, protective, independent, courageous, intelligent, calm
description: Large, powerful white Hungarian livestock guardian dog with a dense double coat, noble bearing, and fiercely loyal, protective nature
history: Ancient Hungarian breed descended from large molosser-type dogs from Tibet. Historically served as royal guard dogs for Magyar kings and fierce livestock guardians, prized for their loyalty and courage in protecting flocks and estates from predators and thieves

name: Labrador Retriever
temperament: Friendly, outgoing, energetic, intelligent, gentle, eager to please
description: Medium to large, strong athletic retriever with short dense coat and friendly outgoing temperament. Consistently one of the most popular breeds worldwide.
history: Originated from St. John's Water Dogs used by fishermen in Newfoundland for retrieving nets and escaped fish. Further developed and standardized in England during the 1800s by English nobles for waterfowl retrieving

name: Lagotto Romagnolo
temperament: Affectionate, intelligent, energetic, loyal, alert, work-focused
description: Medium-sized rustic water retriever with dense, curly, waterproof coat and exceptional sense of smell, specialized as the world's premier truffle-hunting dog
history: Ancient breed from the Romagna region of Italy, originally used as a water retriever in the marshlands. When the marshes were drained, the breed was adapted and became the world's premier truffle-hunting dog.

name: Lancashire Heeler
temperament: Intelligent, alert, energetic, friendly, playful, courageous
description: Small, sturdy herding dog with short legs and a low-set build. Features a short black and tan weatherproof double coat and distinctive foxlike expression with alert nature.
history: Developed in Lancashire, England as an all-purpose farm dog for herding cattle by nipping at heels and for ratting. Believed to be developed from crosses between Welsh Corgis and Manchester Terriers. Nearly extinct by the 1960s but saved through dedicated breeding programs. Recognized by The Kennel Club (UK) in 1981 and AKC in 2024.

name: Leonberger
temperament: Gentle, calm, loyal, friendly, intelligent, confident
description: Giant, majestic working dog with a lion-like appearance, thick water-resistant double coat, and gentle, balanced temperament. This powerful yet serene breed combines an imposing presence with a calm, patient demeanor.
history: Developed in the 1840s by Heinrich Essig in Leonberg, Germany, crossing Newfoundlands, Saint Bernards, and Pyrenean Mountain Dogs to create a 'lion-like' dog resembling the lion on the town crest. Became popular companion for European royalty

name: Lhasa Apso
temperament: Confident, independent, alert, loyal, smart, protective
description: Small, hardy, and sturdy ancient Tibetan breed known for its floor-length coat of hair that parts down the back and alert, confident expression, originally bred as palace and monastery sentinel
history: Ancient breed developed in Tibetan monasteries and palaces over a thousand years ago as indoor sentinel dogs, alerting monks to intruders. Highly prized and rarely left the country until brought to England in 1920s

name: Maltese
temperament: Playful, gentle, affectionate, charming, fearless, alert, adaptable
description: An ancient toy breed from the Mediterranean with a long, silky white coat and charming, playful personality combined with a fearless nature despite their diminutive size
history: One of the world's oldest known breeds dating back over 2000 years, originating from the island of Malta. Historically known as 'Ye Ancient Dogge of Malta' and prized as companions to royalty and aristocracy throughout Mediterranean civilizations and European nobility

name: Miniature American Shepherd
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, devoted, loyal, eager to please, work-focused
description: Small, athletic herding dog with a striking double coat and keen intelligence, essentially a compact version of the Australian Shepherd with intense work drive and devotion
history: Developed in California during the late 1960s from small Australian Shepherds, bred for compact size while maintaining herding ability. Became popular with equestrians traveling to horse shows and was recognized by the AKC Herding Group in 2015.

name: Miniature Pinscher
temperament: Energetic, alert, confident, intelligent, courageous, fearless
description: Small, compact, and elegant toy breed with a distinctive high-stepping 'hackney' gait and spirited personality. Despite resembling a miniature Doberman, this is an older, distinct German breed with a proud carriage and 'big dog' attitude in a small package.
history: An old German breed (Zwergpinscher) developed centuries ago to hunt rats in homes and stables. Not a miniaturized Doberman Pinscher, but a distinct older breed likely descended from German Pinschers with contributions from Italian Greyhounds and Dachshunds.

name: Miniature Schnauzer
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, alert, outgoing, energetic
description: Small, sturdy terrier-type dog with distinctive wiry coat, bushy eyebrows, and characteristic beard, known for its alert, friendly nature and square build
history: Developed in late 19th century Germany by crossing Standard Schnauzers with smaller breeds like Affenpinschers and Poodles to create an all-purpose farm dog and efficient ratter for vermin control and companionship

name: Newfoundland
temperament: Gentle, loyal, devoted, calm, intelligent
description: Massive, powerful working dog known for exceptional water rescue abilities and gentle temperament. Often called the 'gentle giant,' this breed features a thick, water-resistant double coat, webbed feet, and natural swimming ability.
history: Developed by fishermen on the island of Newfoundland for water rescue, hauling nets, and cart pulling. Descended from indigenous water dogs and European breeds brought by fishermen, recognized by major kennel clubs in the 19th century.

name: Norfolk Terrier
temperament: Alert, courageous, affectionate, energetic, playful
description: Small, sturdy, and fearless terrier with a wiry, weather-resistant coat and characteristic drop ears. Known for its spirited, affectionate nature and bred for ratting and companionship.
history: Developed in Norfolk and East Anglia, England in the 1880s-early 20th century as farm dogs to control vermin and hunt foxes. Originally classified as the drop-eared variety of the Norwich Terrier, separated as distinct breed in 1964 by The Kennel Club (UK) and 1979 by the AKC based on ear carriage.

name: Norwich Terrier
temperament: Alert, energetic, affectionate, courageous, outgoing
description: Small, sturdy, and compact terrier with distinctive prick ears, wiry double coat, and lively disposition. Known for its hardy constitution and fearless but affectionate nature.
history: Developed in East Anglia, England in the 1880s as a rugged earth-dog for ratting and fox bolting. Originally grouped with Norfolk Terrier until official separation in 1964 based on ear carriage (Norwich has prick ears). Recognized by AKC in 1979.

name: Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, playful, outgoing, alert, affectionate
description: The smallest of the retrievers, this medium-sized, athletic sporting dog is known for its distinctive reddish coat with white markings and enthusiastic personality. Originally bred for luring and retrieving waterfowl by playing along the shoreline.
history: Developed in early 19th century Nova Scotia, specifically in the Little River Harbour area of Yarmouth County, to 'toll' (lure) ducks within gunshot range by playing along the shoreline, then retrieve shot birds. Recognized by AKC in 2003.

name: Olde English Bulldogge
temperament: Confident, courageous, alert, friendly, loyal
description: Athletic and muscular, medium-sized bulldog breed developed to recreate the healthier, more athletic Regency-era English Bulldog with improved health, stable temperament, and well-balanced features without exaggeration
history: Developed in the 1970s by David Leavitt to recreate the healthier, more athletic bulldog of the 18th and 19th centuries (Regency Period) using crosses of English Bulldog, American Bulldog, American Pit Bull Terrier, and Bullmastiff. Recognized by UKC but not AKC

name: Old English Sheepdog
temperament: Intelligent, gentle, playful, adaptable, affectionate
description: Large, athletic herding dog of great strength with distinctive profuse, shaggy double coat in gray and white, famous for its peek-a-boo hairdo and characteristic bear-like gait
history: Developed in western England in the late 18th century likely from breeds like Bearded Collie and Russian Owtchar. Bred as drovers' dogs to drive cattle and sheep to market. Tails were historically docked to identify them as working dogs exempting them from taxes. Recognized by AKC in 1888

name: Papillon
temperament: Friendly, intelligent, alert, energetic, happy
description: Small, fine-boned, and elegant toy spaniel with distinctive butterfly-like ears (papillon is French for 'butterfly') and silky flowing coat, known for their alert, friendly, and energetic nature
history: Descended from continental toy spaniels that were popular in European courts for centuries, appearing in paintings by masters like Titian, Goya, and Rubens. The breed was refined in France and Belgium, with the original drop-eared variety (Phalène) later joined by the erect-eared 'butterfly' version (Papillon)

name: Pekingese
temperament: Loyal, independent, confident, courageous, affectionate, alert
description: Small, compact toy dog of Chinese nobility with a long, profuse double coat, distinctive flat-faced expression, rolling gait, and regal bearing originally bred for Chinese royalty
history: Ancient breed developed in Chinese imperial court and held sacred in the Imperial Palace in Peking (now Beijing). Exclusively owned by royalty for over 1000 years until Western dogs were brought to England after British troops entered the Forbidden City in 1860 during the Opium Wars.

name: Pembroke Welsh Corgi
temperament: Intelligent, affectionate, alert, outgoing, playful
description: A low-set, strong, and sturdily built herding dog with short legs, fox-like face, alert expression, and naturally bobbed tail. Known for their intelligence, sturdy build, and distinctive appearance.
history: Ancient herding breed from Pembrokeshire, Wales, brought by Flemish weavers in 1107. Developed as a cattle herding dog, their low stature allowed them to nip at cattle's heels and avoid being kicked. Closely associated with British royalty.

name: Pharaoh Hound
temperament: Intelligent, friendly, playful, alert, affectionate
description: Medium-sized elegant sighthound with short tan coat, alert expression, and distinctive ability to 'blush' on nose and ears when excited. A graceful, powerful, and swift breed of ancient origins.
history: National dog of Malta and ancient breed believed descended from Egyptian hunting dogs brought by Phoenician traders over 2,000 years ago. Known as 'Kelb tal-Fenek' (rabbit dog) in Malta, used for rabbit hunting. One of oldest domesticated breeds with depictions found in ancient Egyptian tombs. Recognized by AKC in 1983.

name: Plott Hound
temperament: Loyal, alert, courageous, intelligent, devoted
description: Athletic, streamlined, and powerful scent hound with distinctive brindle coat, known for its intelligence, courage, and exceptional tracking ability. Originally bred for big-game hunting including bear and boar.
history: Developed in the mountains of North Carolina by German immigrant Johannes Georg Plott from German Hanoverian Schweisshunds brought in the 1750s. Perfected over generations for big-game hunting in the Appalachian Mountains. The only coonhound breed not descended from foxhounds and official state dog of North Carolina.

name: Pomeranian
temperament: Alert, intelligent, playful, confident, outgoing
origin: Pomerania region (now parts of Germany and Poland)
description: Small, compact, active toy spitz breed with abundant fluffy double coat, fox-like expression, and plumed tail carried over the back
history: Descended from larger Arctic spitz-type sled dogs and bred down to current small size in the Pomerania region. Popularity greatly increased by Queen Victoria who became a breeder and established distinct breed standards

name: Poodle (Miniature)
temperament: Intelligent, alert, playful, confident, eager to please
description: Elegant, athletic, and intelligent smaller version of the Standard Poodle with a curly, hypoallergenic coat and proud carriage
history: Originally developed as water retrievers in Germany, the name 'Poodle' comes from German 'pudel' meaning 'to splash in water'. Miniature variety was bred down from Standard Poodles for companionship, circus performance, and truffle hunting

name: Poodle (Toy)
temperament: Intelligent, alert, confident, playful, affectionate, loyal, outgoing
description: Smallest Poodle variety with dense curly hypoallergenic coat and alert, intelligent demeanor. An elegant, proud companion dog known for exceptional trainability and performing ability.
history: Despite association with France the Poodle originated in Germany as water retrieving dog from German pudel meaning to splash in water. The Toy variety was bred down from Standard and Miniature Poodles for urban companionship and prized by aristocracy for intelligence and performing ability. AKC recognition 1887.

name: Presa Canario
temperament: Confident, calm, protective, intelligent, loyal, courageous
description: Large, powerfully built mastiff-type dog with robust frame, calm attentive expression, and imposing presence as a confident guardian
history: Ancient breed native to the Canary Islands, originally developed as versatile farm and guard dog for guarding livestock and property, used for catching and holding cattle. Nearly extinct by the 1960s but revived through careful breeding programs in the 1970s

name: Pug
temperament: Affectionate, playful, friendly, charming, adaptable
description: Small, compact, and sturdy toy breed with a distinctive wrinkled, short-muzzled face, curled tail, and charming, mischievous personality
history: Ancient breed originating in China as prized companions for Chinese emperors. Brought to Europe in the 16th century by Dutch traders, became official dog of House of Orange in Holland, gained widespread popularity in Victorian England

name: Puli
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, loyal, alert, devoted, playful
description: Compact, medium-sized Hungarian herding dog known for its distinctive, naturally corded coat resembling dreadlocks, giving it an agile and athletic build with quick, spirited movement
history: Ancient Hungarian sheepdog breed brought by Magyar tribes over 1000 years ago, traditionally used for herding and guarding livestock on the Hungarian plains. Their unique corded coat provided protection from predators and harsh weather. Nearly decimated by World War II but saved by dedicated breeding programs

name: Pumi
temperament: Intelligent, energetic, alert, playful, loyal, confident
description: Medium-sized, agile Hungarian herding dog known for its whimsical, terrier-like expression, distinctive corkscrew-curled coat, and high-set semi-erect ears with an alert, lively attitude
history: Developed in Hungary during the 17th-18th centuries from crossbreeding the native Puli with German and French herding dogs and terriers. Used as versatile farm dogs for herding cattle, sheep, and swine

name: Pyrenean Mountain Dog
temperament: Gentle, confident, protective, independent, calm, loyal
description: Large, majestic, and immensely powerful livestock guardian with thick white double coat and natural guardian instincts developed for mountain work
history: Ancient breed used for centuries by shepherds in the Pyrenees Mountains of France and Spain to guard flocks against predators like wolves and bears. Known as 'Chien de Montagne des Pyrénées' and standardized by the FCI.

name: Rat Terrier
temperament: Alert, intelligent, energetic, friendly, playful, loyal
description: Compact, energetic American terrier with smooth coat and athletic build, developed as a versatile all-purpose farm dog and vermin hunter
history: Developed in early 20th century United States from European terriers brought by British migrants, including Fox Terrier and Manchester Terrier, for farm vermin control and companionship. President Theodore Roosevelt was a notable owner and credited with naming the breed. AKC recognition in 2013.

name: Redbone Coonhound
temperament: Friendly, loyal, eager to please, energetic, affectionate
description: Medium to large athletic hound with a striking solid red coat, known for its speed, agility, and powerful scenting ability. Sleek and muscular, this breed was developed specifically for hunting raccoons and other game.
history: Developed in the American South, primarily in Georgia, during the late 18th and early 19th centuries by Scottish immigrants. Created from red-colored Irish Foxhounds and Bloodhounds to produce a fast, hot-nosed hound for trailing and treeing raccoons and larger game. The breed name is attributed to early breeder Peter Redbone. Recognized by the AKC in 2009.

name: Rhodesian Ridgeback
temperament: Loyal, intelligent, confident, independent, affectionate
description: Large, muscular, and athletic hound with a distinctive ridge of hair running along its back, originally bred to hunt lions in Africa. Known for their dignified, even-tempered nature and loyal disposition.
history: Developed in Southern Africa by crossing native ridged Khoikhoi dogs with European breeds like Mastiffs and Greyhounds. Bred by farmers and hunters for tracking and holding big game, notably lions, at bay. Recognized by South African Kennel Union in the 1920s.

name: Rottweiler
temperament: Confident, loyal, courageous, calm, protective, affectionate
description: Large, robust, muscular working dog with black coat and tan markings, known for great strength, protective instincts, and confident temperament. A loyal and loving guardian breed.
history: Descended from Roman drover dogs, developed in the German town of Rottweil as cattle herders and guard dogs. Known as the 'Butcher's Dog of Rottweil', they protected butchers' money to and from market. Numbers declined with advent of railroads but was revived in early 20th century. Later used for protection and police work

name: Russian Toy
temperament: Alert, intelligent, loyal, playful, affectionate, energetic, outgoing
description: Very small, elegant toy breed with fine bone structure and lively expression, available in both smooth and long coat varieties. Known for their cheerful disposition and fragile build.
history: Developed in Russia from English Toy Terriers in the early 20th century. Nearly extinct after the Russian Revolution but rebuilt from remaining dogs post-WWII, leading to standardization of both smooth and long-coated varieties. Recently recognized by AKC in 2022.

name: Saint Bernard
temperament: Gentle, friendly, calm, patient, loyal, protective
description: A powerful, giant-sized working breed from the Swiss Alps with distinctive markings and massive head, originally bred for mountain rescue. Known for its gentle, patient nature and calm temperament.
history: Developed by monks at the Great St. Bernard Hospice on the border of Switzerland and Italy for rescue work in treacherous Alpine conditions. Used to locate and rescue travelers lost in snow and fog of dangerous Alpine passes

name: Saluki
temperament: Gentle, independent, intelligent, devoted, calm, reserved
description: Ancient, elegant sighthound of the Middle East with graceful build, feathered ears and tail, known for extraordinary speed, endurance, and dignified nature. Bred for hunting gazelle across desert terrain.
history: One of the most ancient domesticated dog breeds, treasured by royalty and Bedouin tribes for thousands of years. Considered sacred by Muslims and revered throughout the Middle East for hunting gazelle and swift prey across desert terrain.

name: Samoyed
temperament: Friendly, gentle, adaptable, alert, intelligent, playful
description: A powerful and graceful medium to large Arctic spitz breed with a thick, all-white double coat and distinctive 'Samoyed smile' created by the upturned corners of the mouth
history: Ancient breed developed by the nomadic Samoyede people of Siberia over 3,000 years ago for herding reindeer, pulling sleds, and companionship. Their thick coats protected them from brutal climate, and they often slept with families for warmth. Brought out of Siberia in late 19th and early 20th centuries. Recognized by AKC in 1906.

name: Schipperke
temperament: Alert, confident, energetic, intelligent, independent, curious
description: Small, compact, tailless spitz-type dog with a distinctive fox-like face, thick double coat, and abundant ruff around the neck. Known as the 'little captain', this agile black dog has a confident demeanor and alert expression.
history: Developed in the Flemish regions of Belgium as a canal barge watchdog and ratter. The name means 'little captain' and the breed served as an adept guardian and vermin hunter on Belgian waterways for centuries.

name: Scottish Deerhound
temperament: Gentle, dignified, calm, loyal, friendly
description: Large, athletic sighthound with rough, wiry coat and dignified bearing, often called the 'Royal Dog of Scotland', bred for coursing giant red deer in the Scottish Highlands
history: Ancient sighthound breed developed in Scottish Highlands to hunt giant wild red deer. Once so prized that ownership was restricted to nobility, nearly went extinct with decline of clan system but was revived in 19th century. Recognized by AKC in 1886.

name: Scottish Terrier
temperament: Confident, independent, alert, intelligent, loyal
description: Small, compact, and sturdy terrier with a distinctive wiry coat, erect ears, beard and eyebrows, and dignified, confident presence
history: One of Scotland's oldest Highland terrier breeds, developed in the Scottish Highlands for hunting vermin in difficult terrain. Recognized by The Kennel Club (UK) in 1883 and the AKC in 1885.

name: Shetland Sheepdog
temperament: Intelligent, loyal, alert, playful, gentle, eager to please
description: Small, agile herding dog from the Shetland Islands, resembling a miniature Rough Collie with a dense double coat, intelligent expression, and alert demeanor. A distinct breed known for its bright, playful nature and collie-like appearance.
history: Developed in the rugged Shetland Islands of Scotland as a small, hardy herding dog for sheep and ponies in harsh conditions. Created by crossing native dogs with Border Collies, Scotch Collies and possibly Spitz breeds. Recognized by AKC in 1911.

name: Shiba Inu
temperament: Alert, confident, intelligent, independent, loyal, courageous
description: An ancient Japanese spitz breed with a small, compact, well-muscled frame and distinctive fox-like appearance. Known for its spirited personality, confident bearing, and agile movement.
